Key Match Events: Kyle Hendricks allowed only a pair of singles and walked two over 7 1/3 innings.
Isaac Paredes and Pete Crow-Armstrong had run-scoring singles in a three-run eighth inning.
Tyson Milller got two outs in the eighth, and Porter Hodge pitched a perfect ninth for his ninth save in 12 chances.
Post-Match Reflections: Kyle Hendricks waved to appreciative fans after what may have been his final start for the Cubs.
Hendricks expressed his emotions, feeling lucky and happy, and mentioned his family being present.
Hendricks plans to keep pitching and would like to stay with Chicago but seems resigned to moving on to another team.
Reds interim manager Freddie Benavides commented on the team's offensive struggles and praised Hendricks' performance.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Cubs manager Craig Counsell sent pitching coach Tommy Hottovy to the mound to pull Hendricks after he reached 81 pitches.
Cincinnati has lost five in a row and was shut out for the 16th time, held to three hits or fewer for the 20th time.
Reds starter Rhett Lowder allowed three hits in five innings and did not allow a home run in his six starts.
